Title: Proof that angle-preserving map is conformal
AcceptedAnswer:
Let $e_1$, $e_2$ be an orthonormal basis of $T_{p}S$. Let: \begin{align*}
\langle d\phi_{p}(e_1), d\phi_{p}(e_1) \rangle &= \lambda_1 \\
\langle d\phi_{p}(e_1), d\phi_{p}(e_2) \rangle &= \mu \\
\langle d\phi_{p}(e_2), d\phi_{p}(e_2) \rangle &= \lambda_2
\end{align*} Now take: \begin{align*}
v_1 &= e_1 \\
v_2 &= \cos\theta\ e_1 + \sin\theta\ e_2
\end{align*} The equation in your question implies that: $$
\cos\theta = \frac{\lambda_1 \cos\theta + \mu \sin\theta}{\sqrt{\lambda_1\left(\lambda_1\cos^2\theta + 2\mu\sin\theta\cos\theta + \lambda_2\sin^2\theta\right)}}
$$ Take $\theta = \frac{\pi}{2}$ to get $\mu = 0$. This implies that: $$
\lambda_1 = \lambda_1 \cos^2\theta + \lambda_2\sin^2\theta
$$ Or $\lambda_1 = \lambda_2$. Hence: \begin{align*}
\langle d\phi_{p}(e_1), d\phi_{p}(e_1) \rangle &= \lambda_1 \langle e_1, e_1 \rangle_{p} \\
\langle d\phi_{p}(e_2), d\phi_{p}(e_2) \rangle &= \lambda_1 \langle e_2, e_2 \rangle_{p} \\
\langle d\phi_{p}(e_1), d\phi_{p}(e_2) \rangle &= \lambda_1 \langle e_1, e_2 \rangle_{p} \qquad (= 0)
\end{align*} Since both $\langle, \rangle_{p}$ and $\langle d\phi_{p}(), d\phi_{p}() \rangle$ are bilinear forms, the above is true for all $v_1, v_2 \in T_{p}S$.

For every $p \in S$ and all $v_1, v_2 \in T_p(S)$, the equality $$\frac{\langle v_1, v_2\rangle}{\lVert v_1 \rVert \lVert v_2 \rVert} = \frac{\langle d\phi_p(v_1), d\phi_p(v_2)\rangle}{\lVert d\phi_p(v_1) \rVert \lVert d\phi_p(v_2) \rVert}$$ holds,
A conformal map satisfies $\langle d\phi_p(v_1), d\phi_p(v_2) \rangle = \lambda(p)^2 \langle v_1, v_2 \rangle_p$ for some nowhere-zero function $\lambda$.
Problem:
Prove that $\phi$ is locally conformal if and only if it preserves angles.
